prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J2310_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: imaging CO (6-5) line and continuum from J2310+1855

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We detect the CO (6-5) line from this object with the PdBI at 5" resolution. The line flux is 1.52+/-0.13 Jy km/s with a FWHM line width of 460 km/s and a line peak flux density of 3.1 +/- 0.3 mJy. The continuum flux density detected at the CO (6-5) frequency is 0.4+/-0.05 mJy. Our previous ALMA observation of the [C II] line suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over a scale of 0.6" (~3.5 kpc) in these millimeter bright z~6 quasars. Here we request to map the CO (6-5) line emission in C34-7 configuration (at ~0.4" resolution). The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] line is 6.0031+/-0.0002. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the CO (6-5) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum emission in ~2 synthesized beams, the surface brightnesses are estimated to be about 1.5 mJy/beam for the CO (6-5) line and 0.2 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we ask for an rms of 0.3 mJy/beam per 100 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line with SNR~5 in each beam in four to five consecutive 100 km/s channels. According to the sensitivity calculator, the required on-source time is about 24.17 minutes and the total observing time is 55.65 minutes, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is ~0.022 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect and resolve the dust continuum emission at SNR~10.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J2310_[CII]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: imaging [C II] line and dust continuum from J2310+1855. The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] line is 6.0031+/-0.0002. Here we set the redshift to 6.002 in the source table to use the same frequency setup in our Cycle 0 [C II] observation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We propose to map the [C II] line and dust continuum emission from J2310+1855. Our ALMA Cycle 0 observation of this object at 0.7" resolution yields a [C II] line flux of 8.95+/-0.46 Jy km/s, a line peak of 21+/-1 mJy, a line width of 390 km/s, and a 263 GHz continuum flux density of 9.1+/-0.1 mJy. The source is marginally resolved with an intrinsic source size of (0.56"+/-0.03")x(0.39"+/-0.04"). Here we will observe this object in the C34-6 or C34-7 configuration (i.e., resolution about or better than 0.2") to resolve the [C II] line and dust continuum emission in 3~4 synthesized beams. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the [C II] line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum. The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] line is 6.0031+/-0.0002. Here we set the redshift to 6.002 in the source table to use the same frequency setup in our Cycle 0 [C II] observation.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum emission into ~4 synthesized beams, we estimate the surface brightnesses to be ~5 mJy/beam in the [C II] line and ~2 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we request 1sigma line sensitivities of 0.3 mJy/beam per 75 km/s. The goal is to resolve the line emission over three to four beams of sky area in four to five consecutive 75 km/s channels with SNR>15 in each beam. This also results in a continuum sensitivity of 0.033 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here) and allow us to detect and resolve the continuum emission from the central few kpc starburst region at very high SNR. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, the corresponding on-source time is 24.78 munits and the total observing time is 1.03 hours, including overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0927_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging CO(6-5) line and dust continuum from J0927+2001

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We detect the CO (6-5) line from J0927+2001 with the PdBI at 5" resolution. The line flux is 0.69 +/-0.13 Jy km/s with a FWHM line width of 600 km/s and a line peak flux density of 1.25 +/- 0.25 mJy.The redshift measured with the CO line is 5.7722+/-0.0006. We estimate the dust continuum emission from previous (sub)mm measurements (Leipski et al. 2013) assuming an optically thin modified blackbody model with an emissivity index of 1.6. The derived flux density at the CO (6-5) frequency is 0.26 mJy. Previous PdBI observation of the [C II] line in this object suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over a scale of 0.6" (~3.5 kpc) and a larger source size of ~10kpc is suggested from our JVLA observation of the CO (2-1) line (Wang et al. 2011). Here we request to map the CO (6-5) line emission in C34-7 configuration (at about 0.4" resolution). We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the CO (6-5) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum emission in ~2 synthesized beams, the surface brightnesses are estimated to be about 0.6 mJy/beam for the CO (6-5) line and 0.13 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we ask for an rms of 0.15 mJy/beam per 300 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line with SNR~4 in each beam in two to three consecutive 300 km/s channels. According to the sensitivity calculator, the reuired on-source time is 32.8 minutes and the total observing time is 1.12 hours, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is about 0.02 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect and resovle the dust continuum emission at SNR~6.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0927_[CII]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging [C II] line and dust continuum from J0927+2001

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We propose to map the [C II] line and dust continuum emission from J0927+2001 at z=5.7722+/-0.0006. Previous PdBI [C II] detection of this object yields a line flux of 5.1 +/- 0.8 Jy km/s, a line peak of 11+/-2 mJy, a line width of 440 km/s, and a 280 GHz continuum flux density of 6.8 mJy. The PdBI observation constrains the source size to be 0.6"+/-0.3". Here we to observe this object in C34-6 or C34-7 configuration (i.e., resolution about or better than 0.2") to resolve the [C II] line and dust continuum emission in 3~4 synthesized beams. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the [C II] line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum emission in ~4 synthesized beams, we estimate the surface brightnesses to be ~2.5 mJy/beam for the [C II] line and ~1.7 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we request 1sigma rms line sensitivities of 0.3 mJy/beam per 100 km/s. The goal is to resolve the line emission over three to four beams of sky area in four to five consecutive 100 km/s channels with SNR>8 in each beam. This also results in a continuum sensitivity of 0.04 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here) and allow us to detect and resolve the continuum emission from the central few kpc starburst region at very high SNR. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, the corresponding on-source time is 28.73 minutes and the observing time is 1.3 hours, including overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J2054_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging CO (6-5) line and dust continuum from J2054-0005

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We detect the CO (6-5) line from this object with the PdBI at 5" resolution. The line flux is 0.34 +/-0.07 Jy km/s with a FWHM line width of 360 km/s and a line peak flux density of 0.9 +/- 0.2 mJy. We estimate the dust continuum emission from previous (sub)mm measurements (Leipski et al. 2013) assuming an optically thin modified blackbody model with a dust temperture of 47 K and an emissivity index of 1.6. The derived flux density at the CO (6-5) frequency is 0.16 mJy. Our previous ALMA observation of the [C II] line suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over a scale of 0.6" (~3.5 kpc) in these millimeter bright z~6 quasars. Here we request to map the CO (6-5) line emission in C34-7 configuration (at about 0.42" resolution). The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] line is 6.0391+/-0.0001. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the CO (6-5) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum emission in ~2 synthesized beams, the surface brightnesses are estimated to be about 0.45 mJy/beam for the CO (6-5) line and 0.08 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we ask for an rms of 0.15 mJy/beam per 300 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line with SNR~3 in each beam in the velocity integrated map. According to the sensitivity calculator, the required on-source time is ~36 minutes and the total observing time is 1.18 hours, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is about 0.02 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect and resovle the dust continuum emission at SNR~4.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J2054_[CII]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging [C II] line and dust continuum from J2054-0005. The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] line is 6.0391+/-0.0001. Here we set the redshift to 6.0379, i.e. the redshift measured from previous CO observations, in the source table to use the same frequency setup in our Cycle 0 [C II] observation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We propose to map the [C II] line and dust continuum emission from this object. Our ALMA Cycle 0 observation of this object at 0.7" resolution yields a line flux of 3.45 +/-0.53 Jy km/s, a line peak of 13.1 +/- 0.5 mJy, a line width of 240 km/s, and a 261 GHz continuum flux density of 3.1+/-0.5 mJy. The source is marginally resolved with an intrinsic source size of (0.35"+/-0.05")x(0.32"+/-0.06"). Here we to observe this object in C34-6 or C34-7 configuration (i.e., resolution of about or better than 0.2") to resolve the [C II] line and dust continuum emission in 3~4 synthesized beams. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the [C II] line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Based on the measurements listed above, we estimate the surface brightnesses to be ~3 mJy/beam the [C II] line and ~0.8 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we request 1sigma line sensitivities of 0.3 mJy/beam per 60 km/s. The goal is to resolve the line emission over four to five beam of sky area in four to five consecutive 60 km/s channels with SNR~10 in each beam. This also results in a continuum sensitivity of 0.03 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here) and allow us to detect and resolve the continuum emission from the central few kpc starburst region at very high SNR. According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, the corresponding on-source time is 32.05 minutes and the total observing time is 1.22 hours, including overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1319_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging CO(6-5) line and dust continuum from J1319+0950

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We detect the CO (6-5) line from this object with the PdBI at 5" resolution. The line flux is 0.43 +/-0.09 Jy km/s with a FWHM line width of 540 km/s and a line peak flux density of 0.8 +/- 0.2 mJy. The continuum flux density detected at the CO (6-5) frequency is 0.31 +/-0.08 mJy. Our previous ALMA observation of the [C II] line suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over a scale of 0.6" (~3.5 kpc) in these millimeter bright z~6 quasars. Here we request to map the CO (6-5) line emission in C34-7 configuration (at about 0.43" resolution). The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] line is 6.1330+/-0.0007. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the CO (6-5) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum emission in ~2 synthesized beams, the surface brightnesses are estimated to be about 0.4 mJy/beam for the CO (6-5) line and 0.15 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we ask for an rms of 0.13 mJy/beam per 400 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line with SNR~ or >3 in each beam in the velocity integrated map. According to the sensitivity calculator, the required on-source time is 37.73 minutes and the total observing time is 1.21 hours, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is about 0.02 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect and resovle the dust continuum emission at SNR~7.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0129_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Image CO (6-5) line and dust continuum from J0129-0035

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
[Configuration and correlator setup]: We detect the CO (6-5) line from this object with the PdBI at 5" resolution. The line flux is 0.37 +/-0.07 Jy km/s with a FWHM line width of 280 km/s and a line peak flux density of 1.2 +/- 0.3 mJy. We estimate the dust continuum emission from previous (sub)mm measurements (Leipski et al. 2013) assuming an optically thin modified blackbody model with a dust temperture of 47 K and an emissivity index of 1.6. The derived flux density at the CO (6-5) frequency is 0.14 mJy. Our previous ALMA observation of the [C II] line suggests a spatial extent of the gas and star formation over scale ~0.6" (~3.5 kpc) in these millimeter bright z~6 quasars. Here we request to map the CO (6-5) line emission in C34-7 configuration (at about 0.4" resolution). The redshift of this object measured with the [C II] line is 5.7787+/-0.0001. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with one window centered at the CO (6-5) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.
[Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum emission in ~2 synthesized beams, the surface brightnesses are estimated to be about 0.6 mJy/beam for the CO (6-5) line and 0.07 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we ask for an rms of 0.2 mJy/beam per 200 km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line with SNR~ or > 3 in each beam in the velocity integrated map. According to the sensitivity calculator, the required on-source time is 30.80 minutes and the total observing time is 1.09 hours, including the overheads. The corresponding continuum sensitivity is ~0.022 mJy/beam (a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows is adopted here), which is sufficient to detect and resovle the dust continuum emission at SNR~3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high resolution imaging to map the gas and star forming activity from five z~6 quasars that were detected in bright millimeter continuum, CO, and [C II] 158 micron line emission. The millimeter bright quasars at the highest redshift probe the formation of the first supermassive black hole (SMBH) and their host galaxies at the reionization era. The Cycle 2 phase of ALMA now open a great opportunity to resolve the continuum, molecular CO, and fine structure line emission from the starburst nuclear region on kpc scales. We here ask for deep imaging of the CO (6-5) line emission from all the five objects in C34-7. We have an ongoing Cycle 1 program to image the [C II] line at ~0.2" resolution from two of them. In this proposal we request to observe [C II] and dust continuum emission from the remaining three objects in C34-6 or C34-7 configuration. These observations will i) measure the surface densities of the molecular, atomic/ionized gas and the star formation efficiency, ii) probe the gas kinematics, iii) and measure the host galaxy dynamical masses. These will allow a complete study of the star formation and the origin of the SMBH-galaxy relations at the earliest epoch.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.1.00901.S, Study of the Interstellar Medium in the Most Luminous Quasar Host Galaxy at the Reionization Era, PI: Ran Wang
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00240.S, Dust continum and [C II] line emission from quasar host galaxies at z~6, PI: Ran Wang 2012.1.00240.S, Mapping Star Formation and Gas Dynamics in Luminous Quasar Host Galaxies at z~6, PI: Ran Wang
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
